title: Intentional Action and Side-Effects in Ordinary Language

findings.main_hypothesis: A person’s intuitions as to whether or not a given side-effect was produced 'intentionally' can be influenced by that person’s attitude toward the specific side-effect in question (specifically whether it is good or bad).

statistical_tests.statistical_hypothesis: Intentionality judgments differ between harm and help conditions.

original_data_points.description: Percentage of participants judging the side-effect as intentional.

findings.main_hypothesis: People are considerably more willing to blame the agent for bad side-effects than to praise the agent for good side-effects.

statistical_tests.statistical_hypothesis: Mean blame in harm condition > Mean praise in help condition.

original_data_points.description: Mean praise/blame scores on a 0-6 scale.

findings.main_hypothesis: The effect observed in Experiment 1 is general and not specific to corporations or environmental damage.

statistical_tests.statistical_hypothesis: Intentionality judgments differ between harm and help conditions in a military context.

original_data_points.description: Percentage of participants judging the side-effect as intentional.

findings.main_hypothesis: The asymmetry in praise and blame assignment may be at the root of the asymmetry in the application of the concept intentional.

statistical_tests.statistical_hypothesis: Praise/blame scores are correlated with intentionality judgments.

original_data_points.description: Correlation between moral judgment and intentionality judgment across both experiments.

overall_original_results.description: Summary of intentionality judgments and moral evaluations across two experiments.
